previous_headings: Required user inputs
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: order estimate ATSM package, user needs specify several general inputs, namely: 1. Desired ATSM class Model type: character vector indicating model type estimated, presented Table 0.1. 2. Risk factor set Economies: character vector containing names economies included system; Global variables: character vector containing labels desired global unspanned factors used model estimation; Domestic variables: character vector containing labels desired domestic unspanned factors used model estimation; Number spanned factors (N): scalar represents number country-specific spanned factors. Note N equal across countries. 3. Sample span Initial sample date: Start date sample period format “dd-mm-yyyy”; End sample date: End date sample period format “dd-mm-yyyy”. 4. Frequency data: character vector specifies frequency time series data. available options : “Annually”, “Quarterly”, “Monthly”, “Weekly”, “Daily Business Days”, “Daily Days”. 5. Stationary constraint QQ-dynamics: logical variable. Choose TRUE impose constraint largest eigenvalue QQ-measure strictly less 11 otherwise, set FALSE. enforcing stationary constraint may prolong model estimation, can improve convergence model. 6. Selected folder save outputs Path selected graphical outputs saved. set NULL, outputs stored user’s temporary directory (accessible via tempdir()). 7. Output label Character vector length one, specifying name used file stores model outputs. One possible example basic model inputs
code: # 1) Model type ModelType <- "JPS original"  # 2) Risk factor set Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") GlobalVar <- c("GBC", "CPI_OECD") # Global variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") # Domestic variables N <- 3 # number of spanned factors per country  # 3) Sample span Initial_Date <- "01-05-2005" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy" Final_Date <- "01-12-2019" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy"  # 4) Frequency of the data DataFrequency <- "Monthly"  # 5) Risk-neutral stationary constraint StationarityUnderQ <- FALSE  # 6) Path to save outputs Folder2Save <- NULL  # 7) Output label OutputLabel <- "Model_demo"

text: influential paper, Bauer, Rudebusch, Wu (2012) (BRW, 2012) shown estimates traditional ATSMs can severely biased due typical small-sample size used studies. result, models may produce unreasonably stable expected future short-term interest, therefore distorting term premia estimates long-maturity bonds. circumvent problem, propose bootstrap-based method relies indirect inference estimation corrects bias present previous works. version 0.3.10.3.1, MultiATSM package accommodates framework proposed BRW (2012) one ATSM types. additional inputs must specified, user intends perform model estimation along lines BRW (2012). : Mean median P-dynamics estimates (Cent_Measure): user must decide whether compute mean median physical dynamics estimates bootstrap iteration. compute mean (median), user must set Mean (Median); Adjustment parameter (gamma): parameter controls degree shrinkage difference OLS estimates BRW (2012)’s bootstrap-based one iteration. value parameter fixed must lie interval ]0;1[]0;1[; Number iteration (N_iter) : total amount iterations used stochastic approximation algorithm burn-; Number bootstrap samples (B): quantity simulated samples used burn-actual iteration; Perform closeness check (checkBRW): flag whether user wishes check root mean square distance model estimates produced bias-correction method generated OLS. Default set TRUE; Number bootstrap samples used closeness check (B_check): default set 100,000; Number burn-iteration (N_burn): quantity iterations discarded first stage bias-correction estimation process. recommended number 15%15\% total number iterations. Eigenvalue restriction (Eigen_rest): set restriction largest eigenvalue PP-measure. Default 11.
code: BRWlist <- within(list(   Cent_Measure = "Mean", gamma = 0.2, N_iter = 500, B = 50,   checkBRW = TRUE, B_check = 1000, Eigen_rest = 1 ), N_burn <- round(N_iter * 0.15))

text: current form, MultiATSM package allows calculation two risk compensation measures: term premia forward premia. particular, nn-maturity bond yield can decomposed sum expected short-rate (Expt(n)Exp_t^{(n)}) term premia (TPt(n)TP_t^{(n)}) components. Technically: yt(n)=Expt(n)+TPt(n) y_t^{(n)} = Exp_t^{(n)} + TP_t^{(n)}  package’s standard form, expected short rate term computed time tt t+nt+n, represents bond’s maturity: Expt(n)=∑h=0nEt[yt+h(1)]Exp_t^{(n)} = \sum_{h=0}^{n} E_t[y_{t+h}^{(1)}]. Alternatively, one perfom decomposition forward rate level (ft(n)f_t^{(n)}), specifically ft(n)=∑h=mnEt[yt+h(1)]+FPt(n)f_t^{(n)} = \sum_{h=m}^{n} E_t[y_{t+h}^{(1)}] + FP_t^{(n)} FPt(n)FP_t^{(n)} corresponds forward premia. case, user must specify logical variable set TRUE computation forward premia desired, FALSE otherwise. set TRUE, user must also provide two-element numerical vector containing maturities corresponding starting ending dates bond maturity. Example:
code: WishFPremia <- TRUE FPmatLim <- c(60, 120)

title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: GVAR() function designed estimate first-order GVAR built country-specific VARX(1,1,1) models. comprehensive discussion GVAR models, see, instance, Chudik Pesaran (2016). GVAR() function requires two key inputs: number country-specific spanned factors (N) set supplementary inputs stored GVARinputs list. former composed four elements: Economies: character vector containing names economies included system; GVAR list risk factors: list risk factors sorted country addition global variables. See outputs DatabasePrep() function; VARX type: string-vector containing desired estimated form VARX(1,1,1). Three possibilities available. “unconstrained” form estimates model without constrains, using standard OLS regressions model equation. “constrained: Spanned Factors” form prevents foreign-spanned-factors impact domestic factor feedback matrix, whereas “constrained: ’ followed name risk factor restricts factor influenced lagged values lagged values star variables. last two cases, VARX(1,1,1) estimated restricted least squares. Transition matrix: estimation GVAR model requires defining measure interdependence among countries economic system. information reported transition matrix, entries reflect degree interconnection across two entities economic system. GVAR setups can estimated using fixed , starting package’s version 0.3.30.3.3, time-varying interdependence weights. Time-varying interdependence implies star factors constructed applying trade flow weights specific year adjust risk factors corresponding year. employ feature, users need specify transition matrix type Time-varying select specific date (year) initial final years within transition matrix. implies trade weights year used solving (link matrices) GVAR system. illustration transition matrix computed average cross-border trade flow weights period spanning years 2006 2019. Therefore, degree dependence across countries assumed fixed entire sample span. Note row sums 11. defined form transition matrix, one can complete GVARinputs list estimate GVAR(1) model. Note CheckInputs parameter set TRUE perform prior consistency check inputs provided GVARinputs.
code: data(GVARFactors) GVARinputs <- list(Economies = Economies, GVARFactors = GVARFactors, VARXtype = "constrained: Inflation") data("TradeFlows") t_First <- "2006" t_Last <- "2019" Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") type <- "Sample Mean" W_gvar <- Transition_Matrix(t_First, t_Last, Economies, type, TradeFlows) print(W_gvar) ##             China    Brazil     Mexico     Uruguay ## China   0.0000000 0.6549066 0.31550095 0.029592464 ## Brazil  0.8268799 0.0000000 0.12340661 0.049713473 ## Mexico  0.8596082 0.1326281 0.00000000 0.007763733 ## Uruguay 0.3811195 0.5497525 0.06912795 0.000000000 data("GVARFactors") GVARinputs <- list(   Economies = Economies, GVARFactors = GVARFactors, VARXtype = "unconstrained",   Wgvar = W_gvar ) N <- 3  GVARpara <- GVAR(GVARinputs, N, CheckInputs = TRUE)

title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: Calculating PP-dynamics parameters form proposed JLL (2015) requires following inputs: () time series risk factors non-orthogonalized form; (ii) number country-specific spanned factors (iii) specification JLLinputs list, includes following elements: Economies: character vector containing names economies included system; Dominant Country: string-vector containing name economy assigned dominant country (applicable JLL original JLL joint Sigma models) None (applicable JLL DomUnit); Wish estimation sigmas matrices: logical variable assumes value equal TRUE user wishes estimation JLL sigma matrices (.e. variance-covariance Cholesky factorization matrices) , FALSE otherwise. Since estimation done numerically, estimation can take several minutes; Sigma non-orthogonalized variance-covariance matrix: save time, user may provide variance-covariance matrix non-orthogonalized dynamics. Otherwise, input set NULL. JLL type: string-vector containing label JLL model estimated according features described Table 0.1. One possible list JLLinputs follows: , P−P-dynamics dimension JLL-based setup can computed :
code: ModelType <- "JLL original" JLLinputs <- list(   Economies = Economies, DomUnit = "China", WishSigmas = TRUE, SigmaNonOrtho = NULL,   JLLModelType = ModelType ) data("RiskFacFull") N <- 3 JLLpara <- JLL(RiskFacFull, N, JLLinputs, CheckInputs = TRUE)

previous_headings: Model Estimation
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: ATSM estimation involves optimizing log-likelihood function optimally selecting model parameters via Optimization() function. Broadly, unspanned risk framework JPS (2014) (, therefore, multi-country extensions) follows model parameterization similar proposed Joslin, Singleton, Zhu (2011). Specifically, requires estimation parameter set consisting 6 elements, namely : Risk-neutral long-run mean short rate (r0); Risk-neutral feedback matrix (K1XQ); Variance-covariance matrix (SSZ) VAR processes; standard deviation errors portfolios yields observed error (se); Intercept physical dynamics (K0Z); Feedback matrices physical dynamics (K1Z). parameters K0Z K1Z estimated part model’s P−P-dynamics known closed form. Likewise, r0 se analytical solutions can factored log-likelihood function. However, remaining parameters (K1XQ SSZ) require numerical estimation. package provides standardized routines set effective initial values, facilitating optimization process. MultiATSM package offers two optimization algorithms: L-BFGS-B Nelder-Mead. default, algorithms run sequentially twice ensure model reaches global optimum. Specifically default bootstrap setup, Nelder-Mead used save time.

what: Examples of full implementation of ATSMs
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: section presents examples use MultiATSM package fully implement ATSMs. console displays messages help user track progress code execution step. , functions package used replicate results presented original papers JPS (2014), CM (2023) CM (2024). See paper replication vignette (included package) detailed reproduction.

previous_headings: Examples of full implementation of ATSMs
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
code: ######################################################################################################## #################################### USER INPUTS ####################################################### ######################################################################################################## library(MultiATSM) # A) Load database data LoadData("CM_2024")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "JPS original" # available options: "JPS original", "JPS global", "GVAR single", "JPS multi", # "GVAR multi", "JLL original", "JLL No DomUnit", "JLL joint Sigma".  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil") # Names of the economies from the economic system GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act") # Global Variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act") # Country-specific variables N <- 2 # Number of spanned factors per country  t0_sample <- "01-12-2007" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy" tF_sample <- "01-12-2019" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy"  OutputLabel <- "Test" # label of the model for saving the file DataFreq <- "Monthly" # Frequency of the data  Folder2Save <- NULL # Folder to save the required graphical outputs. NULL -> temporary directory StatQ <- FALSE # Wish to impose stationary condition for the eigenvalues of each country  # B.1) SPECIFIC model inputs #################################### GVAR-based models ################################################## GVARlist <- list(   VARXtype = "unconstrained", W_type = "Sample Mean", t_First_Wgvar = "2005",   t_Last_Wgvar = "2019", DataConnectedness = TradeFlows ) # VARXtype: Available options "unconstrained" or "constrained" (VARX) # W_type: Method to compute the transition matrix. Options:"Time-varying" or "Sample Mean" # t_First_Wgvar: First year of the sample (transition matrix) # t_Last_Wgvar:  Last year of the sample (transition matrix) # DataConnectedness: measure of connectedness across countries #################################### JLL-based models ################################################### JLLlist <- list(DomUnit = "China") # DomUnit: name of the economy of the economic system, or "None" for the model "JLL No DomUnit" ###################################### BRW inputs  ###################################################### WishBC <- FALSE # Wish to estimate the model with the bias correction method of BRW (2012) BRWlist <- within(list(   Cent_Measure = "Mean", gamma = 0.05, N_iter = 250, B = 50, checkBRW = TRUE,   B_check = 1000, Eigen_rest = 1 ), N_burn <- round(N_iter * 0.15)) # Cent_Measure: "Mean" = compute the mean; "Median" = compute the median # gamma: Adjustment parameter # N_iter:  Number of iteration to be conserved # N_burn:  Number of iteration to be discarded # B: Number of bootstrap samples # checkBRW: wishes to perform closeness check: TRUE or FALSE # B_check: If checkBRW is chosen as TRUE, then choose number of bootstrap samples used in the check  # C) Decide on Settings for numerical outputs WishFPremia <- TRUE # Wish to estimate the forward premia FPmatLim <- c(60, 120) #  If the forward premia is desired, then choose the Min and max maturities of the # forward premia. Otherwise set NA Horiz <- 30 DesiredGraphs <- c("Fit", "IRF", "TermPremia") # "Fit", "IRF", "FEVD", "GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia" WishGraphRiskFac <- FALSE WishGraphYields <- TRUE WishOrthoJLLgraphs <- FALSE  # D) Bootstrap settings WishBootstrap <- TRUE BootList <- list(methodBS = "bs", BlockLength = 4, ndraws = 4, pctg = 95) # methodBS: bootstrap method. Available options: (i) 'bs' ; (ii) 'wild'; (iii) 'block' # BlockLength: Block length, necessary input for the block bootstrap method # ndraws: number of bootstrap draws # pctg: confidence level  # E) Out-of-sample forecast WishForecast <- TRUE ForecastList <- list(ForHoriz = 12, t0Sample = 1, t0Forecast = 131, ForType = "Rolling") # ForHoriz: forecast horizon # t0Sample:   initial sample date # t0Forecast:  last sample date for the first forecast # ForType: Available options are "Rolling" or "Expanding"  ######################################################################################################### ## NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE: ## The sections below automatically process the inputs provided above, run the model ## estimation, generate the numerical and graphical outputs, and save results. #########################################################################################################  # 2) Minor preliminary work: get the sets of factor labels and  a vector of common maturities FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(   t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacro, DomMacro,   FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist, JLLlist, WishBC, BRWlist )  # 4) Optimization of the ATSM (Point Estimates) ModelParaList <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType)  # 5) Numerical and graphical outputs # a) Prepare list of inputs for graphs and numerical outputs InputsForOutputs <- InputsForOutputs(   ModelType, Horiz, DesiredGraphs, OutputLabel, StatQ, DataFreq,   WishGraphYields, WishGraphRiskFac, WishOrthoJLLgraphs, WishFPremia,   FPmatLim, WishBootstrap, BootList, WishForecast, ForecastList )  # b) Fit, IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD, and Term Premia NumericalOutputs <- NumOutputs(   ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels, Economies,   Folder2Save )  # c) Confidence intervals (bootstrap analysis) BootstrapAnalysis <- Bootstrap(   ModelType, ModelParaList, NumericalOutputs, Economies, InputsForOutputs,   FactorLabels, JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save )  # 6) Out-of-sample forecasting Forecasts <- ForecastYields(   ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels, Economies,   JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save )

title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: NumOutputs() function returns object class ATSMNumOutputs, includes autoplot() S3S3 method. method allows users inspect empirical properties chosen specification displaying graphical outputs console, regardless whether saved Folder2Save. user must specify plot type: RiskFactors, Fit, TermPremia, one IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD (suffixed _Factors _Yields). JLL-based models, additional _Ortho suffix generates orthogonalized outputs. examples illustrate responses Brazilian Chinese yield curves global economic activity shock:   Additionally, autoplot() S3S3 method ATSMModelBoot objects—generated Bootstrap() function—allows users assess statistical significance results. example shows responses 12-month bond yields several shocks.   context, autoplot() method requires two additional inputs beyond ATSMModelBoot object. First, takes ATSMNumOutputs object provide point estimates selected output. Second, user must specify plot type, follows structure ATSMNumOutputs objects, added _Boot suffix. worth noting , example, point estimates (black lines) occasionally lie outside confidence bands. surprising, bootstrap carried draws (4).
code: GIRF_all <- autoplot(Out_Example$NumOut, type = "GIRF_Yields") GIRF_all$Brazil$Gl_Eco_Act GIRF_all$China$Gl_Eco_Act GIRF_all_Boot <- autoplot(Out_Example$Bootstrap, Out_Example$NumOut, type = "GIRF_Yields_Boot") GIRF_all_Boot$China$Y12M_China GIRF_all_Boot$Brazil$Y12M_Brazil

title: Paper Replications
text: database used replication constructed Bauer Rudebusch (2017) (BR, 2017) available Bauer’s website. paper, BR (2017) investigate whether macro-finance term structure models better suit unspanned macro risk framework JPS (2014) earlier traditional spanned settings one Ang Piazzesi (2003). Accordingly, BR (2017) intend replicate empirical results reported JPS (2014). R-code used BR (2017) also available Bauer’s website. Supported BR (2017)’s data-set, code uses MultiATSM package estimate key model parameters ATSM along lines JPS (2014). model estimation performed using JPS original modeling setup. tables compare ATSM parameter estimates generated BR (2017) MultiATSM. Overall, one can note differences estimates economically modest. QQ-dynamics parameters  PP-dynamics parameters Portfolio yields errors replicability, important note P−P-dynamics results reported Table 1.2 MultiATSM package make use principal component weights provided BR (2017). matrix simply scaled-version one provided function pca_weights_one_country() package. Accordingly, despite numerical differences weight matrices, methods generate time series spanned factors perfectly correlated. Another difference two approaches relates construction form log-likelihood function (llk): BR (2017) code llk expressed terms portfolio yields, MultiATSM package generates input directly function observed yields (.e. procedures lead equivalent llk Jacobian term).
code: # A) Load database data LoadData("BR_2017")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "JPS original"  Economies <- c("US") # Names of the economies from the economic system GlobalVar <- c() # Global Variables DomVar <- c("GRO", "INF") # Country-specific variables N <- 3 # Number of spanned factors per country  t0_sample <- "January-1985" tF_sample <- "December-2007"  DataFreq <- "Monthly" # Frequency of the data  StatQ <- FALSE # Stationary condition  ######################################################################################################### ############################### NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE ####################################### ######################################################################################################### # 2) Minor preliminary work FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  Yields <- t(BR_jps_out$Y) DomesticMacroVar <- t(BR_jps_out$M.o) GlobalMacroVar <- c()  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,   FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq,   verbose = FALSE )  # 4) Optimization of the model ModelPara <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Paper Replications
text: multi-country framework introduced Candelon Moura (2024) designed enhance tractability large-scale ATSMs, providing deeper understanding intricate global economic mechanisms underlie yield curve fluctuations. framework also reinforces statistical validity inference enhances predictive capabilities models. novel setup, embodied GVAR multi model class, benchmarked findings Jotikasthira, Le, Lundblad (2015), captured JLL original model class. paper showcases empirical illustration involving China, Brazil, Mexico, Uruguay.
code: # A) Load database data LoadData("CM_2024")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "GVAR multi" # Options: "GVAR multi" or "JLL original".  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act", "Gl_Inflation") DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") N <- 3  t0_sample <- "01-06-2004" tF_sample <- "01-01-2020"  OutputLabel <- "CM_jfec" DataFreq <- "Monthly" Folder2Save <- NULL  StatQ <- FALSE  # B.1) SPECIFIC model inputs #################################### GVAR-based models ################################################## GVARlist <- list(   VARXtype = "unconstrained", W_type = "Sample Mean", t_First_Wgvar = "2004",   t_Last_Wgvar = "2019", DataConnectedness = TradeFlows ) #################################### JLL-based models ################################################### JLLlist <- list(DomUnit = "China") ###################################### BRW inputs  ###################################################### WishBC <- TRUE BRWlist <- within(list(   Cent_Measure = "Mean", gamma = 0.001, N_iter = 200, B = 50, checkBRW = TRUE,   B_check = 1000, Eigen_rest = 1 ), N_burn <- round(N_iter * 0.15))  # C) Decide on Settings for numerical outputs WishFPremia <- TRUE FPmatLim <- c(24, 36)  Horiz <- 25 DesiredGraphs <- c("GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia") WishGraphRiskFac <- FALSE WishGraphYields <- TRUE WishOrthoJLLgraphs <- TRUE  # D) Bootstrap settings WishBootstrap <- FALSE #  Set it to TRUE, if bootstrap is desired BootList <- list(methodBS = "bs", BlockLength = 4, ndraws = 1000, pctg = 95)  # E) Out-of-sample forecast WishForecast <- TRUE ForecastList <- list(ForHoriz = 12, t0Sample = 1, t0Forecast = 100, ForType = "Rolling")  ######################################################################################################### ############################### NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE ####################################### #########################################################################################################  # 2) Minor preliminary work: get the sets of factor labels and  a vector of common maturities FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(   t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacro, DomMacro,   FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist, JLLlist, WishBC, BRWlist )  # 4) Optimization of the ATSM (Point Estimates) ModelParaList <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType)  # 5) Numerical and graphical outputs # a) Prepare list of inputs for graphs and numerical outputs InputsForOutputs <- InputsForOutputs(   ModelType, Horiz, DesiredGraphs, OutputLabel, StatQ, DataFreq,   WishGraphYields, WishGraphRiskFac, WishOrthoJLLgraphs, WishFPremia,   FPmatLim, WishBootstrap, BootList, WishForecast, ForecastList )  # b) Fit, IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD, and Term Premia NumericalOutputs <- NumOutputs(   ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels,   Economies, Folder2Save )  # c) Confidence intervals (bootstrap analysis) BootstrapAnalysis <- Bootstrap(   ModelType, ModelParaList, NumericalOutputs, Economies, InputsForOutputs,   FactorLabels, JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save )  # 6) Out-of-sample forecasting Forecasts <- ForecastYields(   ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels, Economies,   JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save )

title: Paper Replications
text: paper, Candelon Moura (2023) delve exploration underlying factors shape sovereign yield curves Brazil, India, Mexico, Russia midst COVID−19-19 pandemic crisis. comprehensively address intricate web global macro-financial particularly health-related interdependencies, study employs modeling approach based GVAR multi type framework. delving aspects, authors aim provide nuanced understanding dynamics influencing sovereign yield curves countries challenging circumstances pandemic.
code: # A) Load database data LoadData("CM_2023")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "GVAR multi"  Economies <- c("Brazil", "India", "Russia", "Mexico") GlobalVar <- c("US_Output_growth", "China_Output_growth", "SP500") DomVar <- c("Inflation", "Output_growth", "CDS", "COVID") N <- 2  t0_sample <- "22-03-2020" tF_sample <- "26-09-2021"  OutputLabel <- "CM_EM" DataFreq <- "Weekly" F2S <- NULL  StatQ <- FALSE  # B.1) SPECIFIC model inputs #################################### GVAR-based models ################################################## GVARlist <- list(   VARXtype = "constrained: COVID", W_type = "Sample Mean", t_First_Wgvar = "2015",   t_Last_Wgvar = "2020", DataConnectedness = TradeFlows_covid ) ###################################### BRW inputs  ###################################################### WishBC <- FALSE  # C) Decide on Settings for numerical outputs WishFPremia <- TRUE FPmatLim <- c(47, 48)  Horiz <- 12 DesiredGraphs <- c("GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia") WishGraphRiskFac <- FALSE WishGraphYields <- TRUE WishOrthoJLLgraphs <- FALSE  # D) Bootstrap settings WishBootstrap <- TRUE #  YES: 1; No = 0. BootList <- list(methodBS = "bs", BlockLength = 4, ndraws = 100, pctg = 95)  ######################################################################################################### ############################### NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE ####################################### #########################################################################################################  # 2) Minor preliminary work: get the sets of factor labels and  a vector of common maturities FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(   t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields_covid, GlobalMacro_covid, DomMacro_covid, FactorLabels,   Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist )  # 4) Optimization of the ATSM (Point Estimates) ModelParaList <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType)  # 5) Numerical and graphical outputs # a) Prepare list of inputs for graphs and numerical outputs InputsForOutputs <- InputsForOutputs(   ModelType, Horiz, DesiredGraphs, OutputLabel, StatQ, DataFreq,   WishGraphYields, WishGraphRiskFac, WishOrthoJLLgraphs, WishFPremia,   FPmatLim, WishBootstrap, BootList )  # b) Fit, IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD, and Term Premia NumericalOutputs <- NumOutputs(   ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels,   Economies, F2S )  # c) Confidence intervals (bootstrap analysis) BootstrapAnalysis <- Bootstrap(ModelType, ModelParaList, NumericalOutputs, Economies, InputsForOutputs,   FactorLabels,   JLLlist = NULL, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, F2S )

title: Multicountry Term Structure of Interest Rates Models
text: MultiATSM R package estimating, analyzing, forecasting multi-country macro-finance affine term structure models (ATSMs). package implements variety models, including JPS, GVAR, JLL frameworks (see complete references ), provides tools bias correction, bootstrap analysis, graphical/numerical outputs.

title: Multicountry Term Structure of Interest Rates Models
text: Estimation multi-country ATSMs (JPS, 2014, JLL, 2015, GVAR, 2023-2024, variants) Flexible input structure macroeconomic yield data Graphical numerical outputs model diagnostics interpretation Bias correction VAR dynamics (BRW, 2012) Bootstrap analysis confidence intervals --sample forecasting

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
text: ModelType character. Model type estimated. Permissible choices: "JPS original", "JPS global", "GVAR single", "JPS multi", "GVAR multi", "JLL original", "JLL DomUnit", "JLL joint Sigma". BRWinputs list. Contains necessary inputs BRW model estimation: Cent_Measure: "Mean" "Median" (unbiased estimation type) gamma: Numeric. Adjustment parameter 0 1. Default 0.5. N_iter: Integer. Number iterations stochastic approximation algorithm burn-. Default 5000. N_burn: Integer. Number burn-iterations. Default 15 B: Integer. Number bootstrap samples per iteration calculating noisy measure biased estimator's mean median. Default 50. check: Logical. Indicates whether perform closeness check. Default TRUE. B_check: Integer. Number bootstrap samples closeness check. Default 100000. Eigen_rest: Numeric. Restriction largest eigenvalue P-measure. Default 1. RiskFactors numeric matrix (Td x K). Time series risk factors. Economies character vector. Names C economies included system. FactorLabels list. Labels variables model. GVARinputs list. Inputs GVAR model estimation (see GVAR). Default NULL. JLLinputs list. Inputs JLL model estimation (see JLL). Default NULL. verbose logical. Flag controlling function messaging. Default TRUE.

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
text: Bias-corrected VAR parameters based framework Bauer, Rudebusch Wu (2012). list contains: KOZ_BC: estimated intercept (K x 1); K1Z_BC: estimated feedback matrix (K x K); SSZ_BC: estimated variance-covariance matrix (K x K); dist: root mean square distance (scalar);

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
text: Td denotes model time series dimension. C number countries system. K denotes total number risk factors.

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
text: Bauer, Rudebusch , Wu (2012). "Correcting Estimation Bias Dynamic Term Structure Models"  function offers independent R implementation informed conceptual framework outlined Bauer, Rudebusch Wu (2012), adapted present modeling context. Related Matlab routines available Cynthia Wu's website (https://sites.google.com/view/jingcynthiawu/).

code: Bootstrap(   ModelType,   ModelParaPE,   NumOutPE,   Economies,   InputsForOutputs,   FactorLabels,   JLLlist,   GVARlist,   WishBC = FALSE,   BRWlist = NULL,   Folder2save = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Generates the bootstrap-related outputs — Bootstrap
text: ModelType character. Model type estimated. Permissible choices: "JPS original", "JPS global", "GVAR single", "JPS multi", "GVAR multi", "JLL original", "JLL DomUnit", "JLL joint Sigma". ModelParaPE list. Point estimates model parameters. See outputs Optimization. NumOutPE list. Point estimates numerical outputs. See outputs NumOutputs. Economies character vector. Names C economies included system. InputsForOutputs list. Inputs generating IRFs, GIRFs, FEVDs, GFEVDs, Term Premia. FactorLabels list. Labels variables present model, returned LabFac. JLLlist list. Inputs JLL model estimation (see JLL). Default NULL. GVARlist list. Inputs GVAR model estimation (see GVAR). Default NULL. WishBC logical. Whether estimate physical parameter model bias correction (see Bias_Correc_VAR). Default FALSE. BRWlist list. Inputs bias-corrected estimation (see Bias_Correc_VAR). Folder2save character. Folder path outputs stored. Default saves outputs temporary directory. verbose logical. Print progress messages. Default TRUE.

title: Generates the bootstrap-related outputs — Bootstrap
text: object class 'ATSMModelBoot' containing: List model parameters draw List numerical outputs (IRFs, GIRFs, FEVDs, GFEVDs) draw Confidence bounds chosen level significance

what: Permissible options - Bootstrap list in InputsForOutputs
title: Generates the bootstrap-related outputs — Bootstrap
text: methodBS : "bs" (standard bootstrap), "wild" (wild bootstrap), "block" (block bootstrap) BlockLength : required input block bootstrap method. Block length must larger 0 smallar model time series dimension (Td). ndraws: number draws. Must positive integer. pctg : confidence level. Must positive integer. Common choices : 68, 90  95.

title: Retrieves data from Excel and builds the database used in the model estimation — DataForEstimation
text: t0 character. Start date sample period format yyyy-mm-dd. tF character. End date sample period format yyyy-mm-dd. Economies character vector. Names C economies included system. N positive integer. Number country-specific spanned factors. FactorLabels list. Labels variables present model, returned LabFac. ModelType character. Model type estimated. Permissible choices: "JPS original", "JPS global", "GVAR single", "JPS multi", "GVAR multi", "JLL original", "JLL DomUnit", "JLL joint Sigma". DataFrequency character. Data frequency. Permissible choices: "Daily Days", "Daily Business Days", "Weekly", "Monthly", "Quarterly", "Annually". Macro_FullData list. Full set macroeconomic data. Yields_FullData list. Full set bond yield data. DataConnect list. Data computing bilateral connectedness measures. Default NULL. Required GVAR-based models. W_type character. Weight matrix type. Permissible choices: "Full Sample" (years), "Sample Mean" (average sample), specific year (e.g. "1998", "2005"). Default NULL. t_First_Wgvar character. First year weight matrix computation. Default NULL. t_Last_Wgvar character. Last year weight matrix computation. Default NULL.

title: Retrieves data from Excel and builds the database used in the model estimation — DataForEstimation

title: Retrieves data from Excel and builds the database used in the model estimation — DataForEstimation

code: DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") GlobalVar <- c("GBC", "CPI_OECD") t0 <- "2006-09-01" tF <- "2019-01-01" Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay", "Russia") N <- 2 ModelType <- "JPS original" FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType) DataFrequency <- "Monthly" MacroData <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "MacroData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) YieldData <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "YieldsData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) DataModel <- DataForEstimation(   t0, tF, Economies, N, FactorLabels, ModelType, DataFrequency,   MacroData, YieldData )

title: Gather data of several countries in a list. Particularly useful for GVAR-based setups (Compute
code: # Load data from excel macro_data <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "MacroData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) yields_data <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "YieldsData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) trade_data <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "TradeData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1`  # Adjust trade data trade_data <- lapply(trade_data, function(df) {   countries <- df[[1]]   df <- as.data.frame(df[-1])   rownames(df) <- countries   df })  # Define features of interest ModelType <- "GVAR multi" Economies <- c("China", "Uruguay", "Russia") GlobalVar <- c("GBC", "CPI_OECD") DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") N <- 3 t0 <- "2006-09-01" tF <- "2019-01-01"   # Compute some inputs FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType) Wgvar <- Transition_Matrix(   t_First = "2006", t_Last = "2019", Economies,   type = "Sample Mean", trade_data )  # Compute GVARFactors GVARFactors <- DatabasePrep(   t0, tF, Economies, N, FactorLabels, ModelType, macro_data,   yields_data, Wgvar )

Inputs JLL model estimation. See details . WishBRW logical. Whether estimate physical parameter model bias correction (see Bias_Correc_VAR). Default FALSE. BRWlist list. Inputs bias-corrected estimation. UnitYields character. Maturity unit yields. Permissible choices: "Month" "Year". Default "Month". CheckInputs logical. Whether perform prior check consistency provided input list. Default TRUE. BS_Adj logical. Whether adjust global series sepQ models Bootstrap setting. Default FALSE. verbose logical. code: # \donttest{ # Example 1: data(GlobalMacro) data(DomMacro) data(Yields)  ModelType <- "JPS original" Economies <- "Mexico" t0 <- "01-05-2007" # Initial Sample Date (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") tF <- "01-12-2018" # Final Sample Date (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") N <- 3 GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act") # Global Variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act") # Domestic Variables FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  DataFreq <- "Monthly"  ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0, tF, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacro, DomMacro,   FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq,   CheckInputs = FALSE, verbose = FALSE )  # Example 2: LoadData("CM_2024")  ModelType <- "GVAR multi"  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") t0 <- "01-05-2007" # InitialSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") tF <- "01-12-2019" # FinalSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") N <- 2 GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act", "Gl_Inflation") # Global Variables DomVar <- c("Inflation") # Domestic Variables FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  DataFreq <- "Monthly" GVARlist <- list(   VARXtype = "unconstrained", W_type = "Sample Mean",   t_First_Wgvar = "2007", t_Last_Wgvar = "2019", DataConnectedness = TradeFlows )  ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0, tF, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacro, DomMacro,   FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist,   CheckInputs = FALSE, verbose = FALSE )  # Example 3: LoadData("CM_2024")  ModelType <- "JLL original"  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Uruguay") t0 <- "01-05-2007" # InitialSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") tF <- "01-12-2019" # FinalSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") N <- 2 GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act", "Gl_Inflation") # Global Variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") # Domestic Variables FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  JLLinputs <- list(DomUnit = "China")  DataFrequency <- "Monthly"  ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0, tF, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacro, DomMacro,   FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq,   JLLlist = JLLinputs,   CheckInputs = FALSE, verbose = FALSE ) # }

code: InputsForOutputs(   ModelType,   Horiz,   ListOutputWished,   OutputLabel,   WishStationarityQ,   DataFrequency,   WishGraphYields = FALSE,   WishGraphRiskFactors = FALSE,   WishOrthoJLLgraphs = FALSE,   WishForwardPremia = FALSE,   LimFP = NULL,   WishBootstrap = FALSE,   ListBoot = NULL,   WishForecast = FALSE,   ListForecast = NULL,   UnitYields = "Month" )

title: Collects the inputs that are used to construct the numerical and graphical outputs — InputsForOutputs
text: ModelType character. Model type estimated. Permissible choices: "JPS original", "JPS global", "GVAR single", "JPS multi", "GVAR multi", "JLL original", "JLL DomUnit", "JLL joint Sigma". Horiz numeric scalar. Desired analysis horizon outputs. ListOutputWished character vector. Desired graphical outputs. Available options: "RiskFactors", "Fit", "IRF", "FEVD", "GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia", "ForwardPremia". OutputLabel character. Name output label stored. WishStationarityQ logical. Whether impose largest eigenvalue Q strictly smaller 1. TRUE impose. DataFrequency character. Data frequency. Permissible choices: "Daily Days", "Daily Business Days", "Weekly", "Monthly", "Quarterly", "Annually". WishGraphYields logical. Whether generate graphs yields. Default FALSE. WishGraphRiskFactors logical. Whether generate graphs risk factors. Default FALSE. WishOrthoJLLgraphs logical. Whether generate orthogonalized JLL-based graphs. Default FALSE. WishForwardPremia logical. Whether generate forward premia graphs. Default FALSE. LimFP numeric vector. Maturities associated start end dates loan. WishBootstrap logical. Whether perform bootstrap-based estimation. Default FALSE. ListBoot list. Contains bootstrap settings: methodBS ("bs", "wild", "block"), BlockLength (numeric), ndraws (numeric), pctg (numeric). WishForecast logical. Whether generate forecasts. Default FALSE. ListForecast list. Contains forecast settings: ForHoriz (numeric), t0Sample (numeric), t0Forecast (numeric), ForType ("Rolling", "Expanding"). UnitYields character. Maturity unit yields. Options: "Month" "Year". Default "Month".

text: Compute maximum likelihood function models

title: Compute the maximum likelihood function of all models — MLEdensity
code: MLEdensity(   K1XQ,   r0,   SSZ,   K0Z,   K1Z,   se,   Gy.0,   mat,   Y,   Z,   P,   Wpca,   We,   WpcaFull,   dt,   Economies,   FactorLabels,   ModelType,   GVARinputs = NULL,   JLLinputs = NULL,   BS_outputs = FALSE,   ExportListOut = TRUE )

title: Compute the maximum likelihood function of all models — MLEdensity
text: K1XQ risk-neutral feedback matrix (N x N CN x CN) r0 long-run interest rate (scalar vector length C) SSZ variance-covariance matrix (F x F) K0Z intercept P-dynamics (F x 1) K1Z feedback matrix P-dynamics (F x F) se Variance portfolio yields observed error (scalar). Default set NULL. Gy.0 matrix contemporaneous terms P-dynamics (F x F) mat vector maturities (years) yields used estimation (J x 1) Y matrix yields used estimation (J x T CJ x T) Z complete set spanned unspanned factors (F x T) P complete set spanned factors (N x T CN x T) Wpca matrix weights portfolios observed without errors (N x J CN x J) matrix weights portfolios observed errors ((J-N) x J C(J-N) x CJ) WpcaFull composite matrix weights portfolios observed without errors dt time interval unit model (scalar). instance, data () monthly, dt <- 12; (ii) quarterly, dt <- 4; (iii) yearly, dt <- 1. Economies string-vector containing names economies part economic system FactorLabels string-list based contains labels variables present model ModelType string-vector containing label model estimated GVARinputs model chosen "GVAR single" "GVAR multi", "GVARinputs" specified (see "GVAR" function) JLLinputs model chosen JLL-based. "JLLinputs" contain () DomUnit, (ii) WishSigmas, (iii) SigmaNonOrtho, (iv) JLLModelType (See JLL function) BS_outputs Generates simplified output list bootstrap setting. Default set FALSE. ExportListOut export complete ATSM outputs. Default TRUE.

title: Compute the maximum likelihood function of all models — MLEdensity
text: Candelon, C. Moura, R. (2024). “Multicountry Model Term Structures Interest Rates GVAR.”  Journal Financial Econometrics 22 (5): 1558–87. Jotikasthira, C; Le, . Lundblad, C (2015). “Term Structures Different Currencies Co-Move?”  Journal Financial Economics 115: 58–83. Joslin, S,; Priebsch, M. Singleton, K. (2014). “Risk Premiums Dynamic Term Structure Models Unspanned Macro Risks.”  Journal Finance 69 (3): 1197–1233. Joslin, S., Singleton, K. Zhu, H. (2011). "new perspective Gaussian dynamic term structure models".  Review Financial Studies. Le, . Singleton, K. (2018). "Small Package Matlab Routines Estimation Term Structure Models."  Euro Area Business Cycle Network Training School - Term Structure Modelling.

title: Overview of Datasets Included in the MultiATSM Package — MultiATSM_datasets
text: GlobalMacro Global macro-financial risk factors, namely global economic activity global inflation. GlobalMacro_covid Global macro-financial risk factors, namely output growth rate U.S. China S&P 500 index. DomMacro Domestic macroeconomic risk factors, namely economic activity inflation. DomMacro_covid Domestic macroeconomic risk factors, namely otput growth, inflation, CDS COVID-19 reproduction rate TradeFlows Bilateral trade flow series used GVAR examples proxy measure cross-country conectdness. TradeFlows_covid Bilateral trade flow series used GVAR examples proxy measure cross-country conectdness. Yields Monthly series bond yields maturity multiple economies. Yields_covid Weekly series sovereign bond yields maturity multiple economies. RiskFacFull Full set risk factors (global domestic) data used throughout package GVARFactors List risk factors used estimation GVAR models. BR_jps_out Replications JPS outputs Bauer Rudebusch (2017) InpForOutEx List inputs illustrative JPS model Brazilian data ParaSetEx List set parameterafter optimization illustrative JPS model Brazilian data NumOutEx List numerical outputs illustrative JPS model Brazilian data Out_Example re-loaded examaple complete list several model outputs. Used package vignette. dataset documented separately using `?GlobalMacro`, `?DomMacro`, `?TradeFlows`, `?Yields`, etc. Datasets ending suffix _covid based used Candelon Moura (2023) cover Brazil, India, Mexico, Russia. remaining datasets correspond Candelon Moura (2024) include Brazil, China, Mexico, Uruguay.

title: Computes the transition matrix required in the estimation of the GVAR model — Transition_Matrix
code: Transition_Matrix(t_First, t_Last, Economies, type, DataConnectedness)

title: Computes the transition matrix required in the estimation of the GVAR model — Transition_Matrix
text: t_First character. Sample starting date (format: yyyy). t_Last character. Sample ending date (format: yyyy). Economies character vector. Names C economies included system. type character. Method computing interdependence. Possible options: "Time-varying": Computes time-varying interdependence returns weight matrices year. "Sample Mean": Returns single weight matrix average weights sample period. Specific year (e.g., "1998", "2005"): Computes time-invariant interdependence specified year. DataConnectedness list data frame. Data used compute transition matrix (e.g., trade flows).

title: Computes the transition matrix required in the estimation of the GVAR model — Transition_Matrix
text: matrix list matrices. Time-varying time-invariant transition matrix depending 'type'.

title: Computes the transition matrix required in the estimation of the GVAR model — Transition_Matrix
text: missing data country particular year, transition matrix include NAs.

title: Computes the transition matrix required in the estimation of the GVAR model — Transition_Matrix
code: t_First <- "2006" t_Last <- "2019" Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") type <- "Sample Mean" # Load data if Connectedness data from excel, otherwise use pre-saved data GetExcelData <- FALSE  if (GetExcelData) {   if (!requireNamespace("readxl", quietly = TRUE)) {     stop(       "Please install package \"readxl\" to use this feature.",       call. = FALSE     )     DataPath <- system.file("extdata", "TradeData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")     tab_names_Trade <- readxl::excel_sheets(DataPath)     list_all_Trade <- suppressMessages(lapply(tab_names_Trade, function(x) {       readxl::read_excel(path = DataPath, sheet = x)     }))     names(list_all_Trade) <- tab_names_Trade      L <- length(list_all_Trade)      for (i in 1:L) {       Countries <- list_all_Trade[[i]][[1]]       list_all_Trade[[i]] <- as.data.frame(list_all_Trade[[i]][, -1])       rownames(list_all_Trade[[i]]) <- Countries     }      DataConnectedness <- list_all_Trade   } } else {   data(TradeFlows)   DataConnectedness <- TradeFlows }  W_mat <- Transition_Matrix(t_First, t_Last, Economies, type, DataConnectedness)
